docs.title: NLS Compiler
docs.text:
The source code is English. The compiled artifact is Python.

NLS is a programming language where specifications are written in plain English that anyone can read—managers, auditors, domain experts—not just programmers. The nlsc compiler translates .nl files into executable Python with full type hints, validation, and documentation.

docs.title: Why NLS?
docs.text:
• Readable by everyone — Non-programmers can review business logic
  • Auditable — Clear mapping from intent to implementation
  • Testable — Specifications include test cases
  • Versionable — Lock files ensure reproducibility
  • Toolable — Tree-sitter grammar enables IDE support

docs.title: Quick Example
docs.text:
@module calculator
@target python

[divide]
PURPOSE: Divide two numbers safely
INPUTS:
  - numerator: number
  - divisor: number
GUARDS:
  - divisor must not be zero -> ValueError("Cannot divide by zero")
RETURNS: numerator / divisor

Compiles to:

def divide(numerator: float, divisor: float) -> float:
    """Divide two numbers safely."""
    if divisor == 0:
        raise ValueError("Cannot divide by zero")
    return numerator / divisor

docs.title: Antigravity Prompt: Greenfield NLS (Natural Language Source) MVP
docs.text: Role: You are a Founding Engineer and Language Designer. Context: We are starting a new project called Natural Language Source (NLS). Reference Material: Read PRD.md in the current directory carefully, specifically focusing on Phase 1: Foundation and the Strategic Considerations (MVP Focus).

docs.title: The Mission
docs.text:
Your goal is to build the Phase 1 MVP of NLS. We are not building the VS Code extension, the compliance standard, or the legacy atomization tools yet. We are building the Compiler (nlsc) and defining the Language Schema.

The Thesis: "The conversation is the programming. The .nl file is the receipt. The code is the artifact."

docs.title: Success Criteria for this Session
docs.text:
By the end of this session, we must have a working CLI tool (nlsc) that can:

  1. Initialize a new project (nlsc init).
  2. Read a valid .nl file (like the math example in Appendix B of the PRD).
  3. Compile it into executable Python code using a deterministic process (mock the LLM part if needed, or use an available API).
  4. Verify that the generated code runs.

docs.title: Technical Stack & Constraints
docs.text:
• Language: Python (for both the compiler implementation and the target language).
  • Architecture: Modular (Parser -> Resolver -> Emitter).
  • No "Big Bang": detailed parsing logic (like Tree-sitter) is good if possible, but a robust regex/structured parser is acceptable for V0 to get the "Math" example working immediately.
  • Determinism: The compiler must be capable of using a lockfile concept, even if rudimentary.

docs.title: Step 1: Schema Definition
docs.text:
Define the strict structure of an ANLU (Atomic Natural Language Unit).

  • Create nl-schema.yaml or a formal EBNF/Grammar definition.
  • Must include: Identifier, Purpose, Inputs, Logic, Returns.

docs.title: Step 2: The CLI Scaffold
docs.text:
Create the nlsc entry point.

  • nlsc init: Generates nl.config.yaml and folder structure.
  • nlsc compile <file.nl>: The core command.

docs.title: Step 3: The Compiler Core
docs.text:
Implement the compilation pipeline:

  • Parser: Read .nl files into an AST (list of ANLUs).
  • Resolver: Check simple dependencies (if ANLU A depends on B).
  • Emitter (LLM Integration):
  • Since we are in a dev environment, use a prompt-template approach.
  • Input: ANLU structure.
  • System Prompt: "You are the NLS Compiler. Translate this ANLU to Python."
  • Output: Python code block.
  • Constraint: If LLM tools are unavailable, implement a "Mock LLM" that handles the Math example deterministically via regex for demonstration.

docs.title: Step 4: Verification (The "Math" Example)
docs.text: Create the exact src/math.nl file from Appendix B. Run nlsc compile src/math.nl. Verify src/math.py is generated. Run the python code to prove add(2,3) == 5.

docs.title: Your First Action
docs.text: Analyze PRD.md and propose the exact file structure you are about to build. Then, ask for approval to proceed with scaffolding.

docs.title: Architecture
docs.text: This document describes the internal architecture of the NLS compiler.

docs.title: Pipeline Overview
docs.text:
flowchart LR
    A[".nl file"] --> B[Parser]
    B --> C[AST]
    C --> D[Resolver]
    D --> E[Emitter]
    E --> F[".py file"]
    E --> G[".nl.lock"]

The compiler follows a classic pipeline architecture:

  1. Parser — Converts .nl text to AST
  2. Resolver — Validates dependencies and ordering
  3. Emitter — Generates Python code
  4. Lockfile — Records hashes for reproducibility

docs.title: Core Modules
docs.text: Module Purpose Lines parser.py Regex-based parser ~500 parser_treesitter.py Tree-sitter parser ~600 resolver.py Dependency resolution ~100 emitter.py Python code generation ~400 lockfile.py Hash computation and storage ~200 schema.py AST data structures ~300

docs.title: CLI Modules
docs.text: Module Purpose cli.py Command-line interface graph.py Visualization (Mermaid, DOT, ASCII) diff.py Change detection watch.py File watcher atomize.py Python → NL extraction

docs.title: Regex Parser (Default)
docs.text:
The regex parser uses pattern matching to tokenize and parse .nl files.

# Pattern examples from parser.py
ANLU_START = r"^\[([a-z][a-z0-9.-]*)\]\s*$"
DIRECTIVE = r"^@(module|version|target|imports)"
SECTION = r"^(PURPOSE|INPUTS|GUARDS|LOGIC|RETURNS|DEPENDS|EDGE CASES):"

Pros:

  • Zero dependencies
  • Fast for simple files
  • Easy to understand

Cons:

  • Limited error recovery
  • Complex patterns for edge cases

docs.title: Tree-sitter Parser
docs.text:
The tree-sitter parser uses a formal grammar for parsing.

# Install tree-sitter support
pip install nlsc[treesitter]

# Use tree-sitter parser
nlsc --parser treesitter compile src/auth.nl

Pros:

  • Better error recovery
  • Incremental parsing
  • Foundation for LSP/IDE support

Cons:

  • Requires native dependency
  • Slightly more complex setup

docs.title: AST Schema
docs.text:
The AST is defined in schema.py:

@dataclass
class NLFile:
    module: ModuleDirective
    version: str | None
    target: str
    imports: list[str]
    anlus: list[ANLU]
    types: list[TypeDef]
    tests: list[TestSpec]
    literals: list[LiteralBlock]

@dataclass
class ANLU:
    identifier: str
    purpose: str
    inputs: list[InputDef]
    guards: list[Guard]
    logic: list[LogicStep]
    returns: str
    depends: list[str]
    edge_cases: list[EdgeCase]

docs.title: Resolution
docs.text:
The resolver validates:

  1. Dependency existence — All DEPENDS references exist
  2. Cycle detection — No circular dependencies
  3. Ordering — Topological sort for code generation
result = resolve_dependencies(nl_file)
if not result.success:
    for error in result.errors:
        print(f"{error.anlu_id}: {error.message}")

docs.title: Code Emission
docs.text: The emitter transforms AST to Python:

docs.title: ANLU → Function
docs.text:
[add]
PURPOSE: Add two numbers
INPUTS:
  - a: number
  - b: number
RETURNS: a + b

Becomes:

def add(a: float, b: float) -> float:
    """Add two numbers."""
    return a + b

docs.title: @type → Dataclass
docs.text:
@type Point {
  x: number
  y: number
}

Becomes:

@dataclass
class Point:
    """Point type."""
    x: float
    y: float

docs.title: GUARDS → Validation
docs.text:
GUARDS:
  - divisor must not be zero -> ValueError("Cannot divide by zero")

Becomes:

if divisor == 0:
    raise ValueError("Cannot divide by zero")

docs.title: Lockfile
docs.text:
Lockfiles ensure reproducible builds:

# example.nl.lock
version: "1.0"
source_hash: "a1b2c3..."
target_hash: "d4e5f6..."
anlus:
  add:
    hash: "abc123..."
    inputs: ["a: number", "b: number"]
    returns: "a + b"
  multiply:
    hash: "def456..."
    inputs: ["a: number", "b: number"]
    returns: "a × b"
llm_backend: "mock"
compiled_at: "2024-01-15T10:30:00Z"

The lockfile enables:

  • Change detection (nlsc diff)
  • Reproducible builds
  • Audit trails

docs.title: Adding a New Target
docs.text:
1. Create emitter_<target>.py
  2. Implement emit_<target>(nl_file: NLFile) -> str
  3. Register in cli.py compile command

docs.title: Adding a New Parser Feature
docs.text:
1. Update grammar in tree-sitter-nl/grammar.js
  2. Regenerate with npx tree-sitter generate
  3. Update parser_treesitter.py to handle new nodes
  4. Update parser.py with matching regex patterns

docs.title: Adding a New CLI Command
docs.text:
1. Create cmd_<name> function in cli.py
  2. Add subparser in main()
  3. Add case in command dispatch

docs.title: CLI Reference
docs.text: The nlsc command-line interface provides 8 commands for working with NLS files.

docs.title: Global Options
docs.text:
nlsc [--parser {regex,treesitter}] [--version] [--help] <command>
Option Description --parser Parser backend: regex (default) or treesitter --version Show version number --help Show help message

docs.title: nlsc init
docs.text:
Initialize a new NLS project with standard folder structure.

nlsc init [path]
Argument Description path Project directory (default: current directory)

Example:

nlsc init my-project

Creates:

my-project/
├── nl.config.yaml    # Project configuration
├── src/              # Source .nl files
│   └── __init__.py
└── tests/            # Generated tests
    └── __init__.py

docs.title: nlsc compile
docs.text:
Compile a .nl file to the target language (currently Python).

nlsc compile <file> [-t TARGET] [-o OUTPUT]
Option Description file Path to .nl file -t, --target Target language (default: python) -o, --output Output file path

Examples:

# Basic compile
nlsc compile src/auth.nl

# Compile with tree-sitter parser
nlsc --parser treesitter compile src/auth.nl

# Specify output file
nlsc compile src/auth.nl -o lib/auth.py

Generated files:

  • <name>.py — Python module
  • test_<name>.py — Test file (if @test blocks present)
  • <name>.nl.lock — Lockfile for reproducibility

docs.title: nlsc verify
docs.text:
Validate a .nl file without generating code. Checks syntax and dependencies.

nlsc verify <file>

Example:

nlsc verify src/order.nl

Output:

Verifying src/order.nl (parser: regex)...
  ✓ Syntax valid: 5 ANLUs
  ✓ Dependencies valid
  ✓ All ANLUs valid

Verification passed!

docs.title: nlsc test
docs.text:
Run @test specifications from a .nl file.

nlsc test <file> [-v]
Option Description file Path to .nl file -v, --verbose Verbose output

Example:

nlsc test src/math.nl -v

The command:

  1. Compiles the .nl file to a temp directory
  2. Generates test code from @test blocks
  3. Runs pytest on the generated tests

docs.title: nlsc graph
docs.text:
Generate dependency and dataflow visualizations.

nlsc graph <file> [-f FORMAT] [-a ANLU] [--dataflow] [-o OUTPUT]
Option Description file Path to .nl file -f, --format Output format: mermaid (default), dot, ascii -a, --anlu Specific ANLU for dataflow visualization --dataflow Show dataflow instead of FSM states -o, --output Output file path (default: stdout)

Examples:

# Module dependency graph
nlsc graph src/order.nl --format mermaid

# Dataflow for specific ANLU
nlsc graph src/order.nl --anlu process-order --dataflow

# Export as DOT for Graphviz
nlsc graph src/order.nl --format dot -o deps.dot

docs.title: nlsc diff
docs.text:
Show changes since last compile by comparing against the lockfile.

nlsc diff <file> [--stat] [--full]
Option Description file Path to .nl file --stat Show summary only --full Show full unified diff

Examples:

# Show changed ANLUs
nlsc diff src/api.nl

# Summary statistics
nlsc diff src/api.nl --stat

# Full unified diff
nlsc diff src/api.nl --full

docs.title: nlsc watch
docs.text:
Watch a directory for .nl file changes and automatically recompile.

nlsc watch [dir] [-q] [-t] [-d DEBOUNCE]
Option Description dir Directory to watch (default: current) -q, --quiet Suppress success messages -t, --test Run tests after successful compile -d, --debounce Debounce interval in ms (default: 100)

Examples:

# Watch current directory
nlsc watch

# Watch with tests
nlsc watch src/ --test

# Quiet mode with custom debounce
nlsc watch src/ -q -d 500

Press Ctrl+C to stop watching.

docs.title: nlsc atomize
docs.text:
Extract ANLUs from existing Python source code (reverse compilation).

nlsc atomize <file> [-o OUTPUT] [-m MODULE]
Option Description file Path to Python file -o, --output Output .nl file path -m, --module Module name for generated .nl

Example:

nlsc atomize legacy/utils.py -o src/utils.nl -m utils

This extracts functions from Python and generates corresponding ANLU blocks.

docs.title: Exit Codes
docs.text: Code Meaning 0 Success 1 Error (parse error, validation failure, etc.)

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text: Variable Description NLSC_PARSER Default parser backend (regex or treesitter)

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text:
Project settings are stored in nl.config.yaml:

project:
  name: my-project
  version: 0.1.0

compiler:
  default_target: python
  llm_backend: mock
  cache_strategy: aggressive

targets:
  python:
    version: ">=3.11"
    style: black
    type_hints: strict

validation:
  require_purpose: true
  require_guards: false
  max_anlu_complexity: 10

docs.title: Core NLS Semantics
docs.text: This document defines the target-neutral semantic core of NLS. All target emitters (Python, TypeScript, etc.) must preserve these semantics while adapting to target-specific idioms.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
NLS semantics are divided into:

  1. Core Semantics — Must behave identically across all targets
  2. Target Semantics — May differ in representation but must preserve behavior
  3. Implementation Details — Left to target discretion

docs.title: Literals
docs.text:
Literal Type NLS Syntax Semantics Number 42, 3.14, -1 IEEE 754 double precision floating point String "hello", 'world' UTF-8 encoded text Boolean true, false Two-valued logic None none, null Absence of value List [1, 2, 3] Ordered, mutable sequence Dict {key: value} Key-value map (literal syntax uses string keys; type dict of K to V allows any hashable key)

Invariants: - Numbers: All targets use IEEE 754 doubles (precision may vary for integers) - Strings: UTF-8 encoding; immutable in semantics - Lists: 0-indexed; mutable; may be heterogeneous if element type is any

docs.title: Arithmetic
docs.text:
Operator Meaning Operand Types Result Type + Addition number, number number - Subtraction number, number number *, × Multiplication number, number number /, ÷ Division number, number number % Modulo number, number number

Invariants: - Division by zero raises DivisionError - Integer division uses // or explicit floor(a / b)

docs.title: Comparison
docs.text:
Operator Meaning == Structural equality !=, ≠ Structural inequality <, > Ordering <=, >=, ≤, ≥ Inclusive ordering

Invariants: - Equality is structural, not reference-based - Ordering is defined for numbers and strings; undefined for other types

docs.title: Logical
docs.text:
Operator Meaning and, && Logical AND (short-circuit) or, \|\| Logical OR (short-circuit) not, ! Logical NOT

Invariants: - Short-circuit evaluation is required - Truthiness: false, none, 0, "", [] are falsy; all else truthy

docs.title: Function Calls
docs.text:
function_name(arg1, arg2, ...)

Semantics: - Arguments evaluated left-to-right - Passed by value (for primitives) or by reference (for objects) - Return value is the expression result of the function body

docs.title: Field Access
docs.text:
object.field

Semantics: - Accesses named field on object - Raises AttributeError if field doesn't exist - For types with @invariant, field access on valid objects always succeeds

docs.title: Let-Bindings
docs.text:
1. Calculate result -> result

Semantics: - Binds a value to a name - Bindings are immutable by default in NLS semantics - Scope is local to the containing function

Target Mapping: - Python: result = <expression> (relies on convention, not enforcement) - TypeScript: const result = <expression> (enforced)

docs.title: Conditionals
docs.text:
NLS uses guard conditions for early exit:

GUARDS:
  - amount > 0 -> ValueError("Amount must be positive")

For inline conditionals in LOGIC:

3. IF discount_rate > 0 THEN apply discount -> final

Semantics: - Guards are evaluated top-to-bottom - First failing guard raises its error - IF/THEN/ELSE is an expression, not statement (always has a value)

docs.title: Early Return
docs.text:
EDGE CASES:
  - Empty list -> return none

Semantics: - Immediately exits function with given value - Guards that fail cause early exit with error

docs.title: Primitives
docs.text: NLS Type Semantic Meaning Python TypeScript number IEEE 754 double float number string UTF-8 text str string boolean true/false bool boolean none Null value None null void No return None void any Dynamic typing Any any

docs.title: Compound Types
docs.text: NLS Type Meaning Python TypeScript list of T Ordered sequence list[T] T[] dict of K to V Key-value map dict[K, V] Record<K, V> T?, optional T Nullable Optional[T] T \| null T \| U Union T \| U T \| U

docs.title: User-Defined Types
docs.text:
@type Order {
  id: string, required
  items: list of OrderItem
  total: number
}

Semantics: - Creates a record type with named fields - Fields have types and optional constraints - required fields must be provided at construction - Omitting required allows field to be optional

Invariants: - Type fields are accessed by name - Field order is preserved (important for some serialization) - Types are structural, not nominal (duck typing)

docs.title: Type Aliases
docs.text:
@type UserId = string
@type OrderList = list of Order

Semantics: - Creates an alias; semantically equivalent to underlying type - May be treated as distinct by some targets (for documentation)

docs.title: Error Model
docs.text: NLS uses typed errors raised through guards.

docs.title: Guard Errors
docs.text:
GUARDS:
  - token must not be empty -> AuthError(MISSING, "Token required")

Components: 1. Error Type: AuthError, ValueError, ValidationError 2. Error Code (optional): MISSING, INVALID_FORMAT 3. Message: Human-readable description

Semantics: - Guards fail fast (first violation wins) - Error types map to target exception/error classes - Standard errors: ValueError, TypeError, RuntimeError

docs.title: Error Propagation
docs.text:
Design Decision: NLS uses exceptions, not Result types.

Rationale: - Matches Python's natural error model - Keeps ANLU specifications focused on happy path - Guards explicitly document expected failures

Invariants: - Errors propagate up call stack until caught - Uncaught errors terminate execution - All guard errors are documented in specification

docs.title: Semantic Invariants
docs.text: These MUST be preserved by all target emitters:

docs.title: 1. Guard Ordering
docs.text: Guards are evaluated in specification order. This is observable when guards have side effects (e.g., logging).

docs.title: 2. Logic Step Dataflow
docs.text: Variables assigned in earlier LOGIC steps are available in later steps. Emitters must preserve this dependency order.

docs.title: 3. Type Constraints
docs.text: Field constraints (required, min:, max:) are enforced at construction time. Objects with invariants are always valid after construction.

docs.title: 4. Test Semantics
docs.text: @test blocks execute in isolation. Each test case is independent—no shared state.

docs.title: 5. Property Semantics
docs.text: @property assertions hold for all valid inputs. Emitters should generate property-based tests (using Hypothesis, fast-check, etc.).

docs.title: Target-Specific Allowances
docs.text: These MAY differ between targets:

docs.title: Performance Characteristics
docs.text:
• List indexing complexity (O(1) vs O(n))
  • String concatenation strategy
  • Memory layout of types

docs.title: Runtime Representation
docs.text:
• How types are encoded at runtime
  • Debug string formats
  • Stack trace formatting

docs.title: Idioms
docs.text:
• Naming conventions in generated code (snake_case vs camelCase)
  • Import style (relative vs absolute)
  • Documentation format (docstrings vs JSDoc)

docs.title: Python Target Mapping
docs.text: This section documents the Core NLS → Python mapping.

docs.title: Types
docs.text: NLS Python number float (or int for known integers) string str boolean bool none None list of T list[T] dict of K to V dict[K, V] T? Optional[T] @type X @dataclass class X

docs.title: Errors
docs.text: NLS Error Python Exception ValueError ValueError TypeError TypeError RuntimeError RuntimeError DivisionError ZeroDivisionError Custom XError class XError(Exception)

docs.title: Guards
docs.text:
GUARDS:
  - amount > 0 -> ValueError("Message")

Becomes:

if not (amount > 0):
    raise ValueError("Message")

docs.title: Logic Steps
docs.text:
LOGIC:
  1. Calculate tax -> tax
  2. Add fee -> total

Becomes:

tax = calculate_tax(...)  # Step 1
total = tax + fee         # Step 2

docs.title: TypeScript Target (Planned)
docs.text: Will require: - number → number (same IEEE 754) - @type → interface or type - Guards → thrown Error objects - Properties → fast-check tests

docs.title: Result Type Option
docs.text:
Future version may support:

@config error_model = "result"

[divide]
RETURNS: Result<number, DivisionError>

This would generate Either/Result types instead of exceptions.

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text: This guide will walk you through installing NLS and creating your first compiled specification.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
From PyPIWith Tree-sitter ParserDevelopment Setup 
pip install nlsc

pip install "nlsc[treesitter]"

The tree-sitter parser provides faster parsing and better error recovery.

git clone https://github.com/Mnehmos/mnehmos.nls.lang.git
cd mnehmos.nls.lang
pip install -e ".[dev,treesitter]"

docs.title: Initialize a Project
docs.text:
Create a new NLS project with the proper folder structure:

nlsc init my-project
cd my-project

This creates:

my-project/
├── nl.config.yaml    # Project configuration
├── src/              # Source .nl files
│   └── __init__.py
└── tests/            # Generated tests
    └── __init__.py

docs.title: Your First .nl File
docs.text:
Create src/calculator.nl:

@module calculator
@target python

[add]
PURPOSE: Add two numbers together
INPUTS:
  - a: number
  - b: number
RETURNS: a + b

[divide]
PURPOSE: Divide two numbers safely
INPUTS:
  - numerator: number
  - divisor: number
GUARDS:
  - divisor must not be zero -> ValueError("Cannot divide by zero")
RETURNS: numerator / divisor

@test [add] {
  add(2, 3) == 5
  add(-1, 1) == 0
}

docs.title: Compile to Python
docs.text:
nlsc compile src/calculator.nl

Output:

Compiling src/calculator.nl (parser: regex)...
  ✓ Parsed 2 ANLUs
  ✓ Resolved dependencies
  ✓ Generated calculator.py (25 lines)
  ✓ Generated test_calculator.py
  ✓ Updated calculator.nl.lock

Compilation complete!

docs.title: Run the Tests
docs.text:
nlsc test src/calculator.nl

Output:

Running 2 test cases from src/calculator.nl...
  • [add]: 2 cases

✓ All 2 tests passed!

docs.title: Use the Generated Code
docs.text:
from src.calculator import add, divide

result = add(2, 3)  # 5
ratio = divide(10, 2)  # 5.0

try:
    divide(1, 0)
except ValueError as e:
    print(e)  # "Cannot divide by zero"

docs.title: Language Specification
docs.text: This document defines the complete syntax of .nl files.

docs.title: File Structure
docs.text:
An .nl file consists of:

  1. Directives — Module metadata (@module, @version, @target, @imports)
  2. ANLU Blocks — Function specifications ([name])
  3. Type Definitions — Custom types (@type)
  4. Test Blocks — Test specifications (@test)
  5. Literal Blocks — Code escape hatches (@literal)
  6. Comments — Lines starting with #

docs.title: @module
docs.text:
Required. Declares the module name.

@module calculator

Pattern: ^[a-z][a-z0-9_]*$ (lowercase snake_case)

docs.title: @version
docs.text:
Optional semantic version.

@version 1.0.0

docs.title: @target
docs.text:
Required. Specifies the compilation target.

@target python

Supported: python (more coming)

docs.title: @imports
docs.text:
Optional comma-separated import list.

@imports jwt, datetime, typing

docs.title: ANLU Blocks
docs.text:
ANLU (Atomic Natural Language Unit) blocks define functions.

[function-name]
PURPOSE: Single sentence describing what this does
INPUTS:
  - param1: type
  - param2: type, optional
GUARDS:
  - condition -> ErrorType("message")
LOGIC:
  1. Description of step -> variable
  2. Another step
EDGE CASES:
  - condition -> behavior
RETURNS: expression
DEPENDS: [other-function], [another]

docs.title: Identifier
docs.text:
ANLU names use kebab-case:

[calculate-tax]
[is-empty]
[validate-user-token]

Pattern: ^[a-z][a-z0-9-]*$

For methods, use dot notation:

[User.validate]
[Order.calculate-total]

docs.title: PURPOSE
docs.text:
Required. Single sentence in imperative mood.

PURPOSE: Calculate the total price including tax

docs.title: INPUTS
docs.text:
Typed parameter list with optional constraints.

INPUTS:
  - amount: number
  - rate: number, "Tax rate as decimal"
  - currency: string, optional

Bullets can be •, -, or *.

docs.title: GUARDS
docs.text:
Preconditions with error mappings.

GUARDS:
  - amount must be non-negative -> ValueError("Amount cannot be negative")
  - rate must be between 0 and 1 -> ValidationError(INVALID_RATE, "Rate must be 0-1")

docs.title: LOGIC
docs.text:
Numbered steps describing the algorithm.

LOGIC:
  1. Calculate base tax -> tax
  2. Add service fee if applicable -> fee
  3. Combine tax and fee -> total

Steps can include:

  • Output binding: -> variable
  • Conditionals: IF condition THEN action
  • State markers: [state] action

docs.title: EDGE CASES
docs.text:
Explicit boundary condition handling.

EDGE CASES:
  - Zero amount -> return 0
  - Empty list -> return None

docs.title: RETURNS
docs.text:
Required. Output expression or type.

RETURNS: base + tax
RETURNS: TaxResult with amount, effective_rate
RETURNS: list of Order

docs.title: DEPENDS
docs.text:
Dependencies on other ANLUs.

DEPENDS: [validate-input], [calculate-base]

docs.title: Primitives
docs.text: Type Description number Integer or float string Text boolean true / false void No return value any Dynamic typing escape hatch

docs.title: Composites
docs.text:
List:

list of number
list of User

Optional:

string?
User?

Map:

map of string to number

Union:

string | number
Success | Error

docs.title: Type Definitions
docs.text:
Define custom types with @type:

@type Point {
  x: number
  y: number
}

@type Order {
  id: string, required
  items: list of OrderItem
  total: number, "Order total in cents"
  status: string
}

docs.title: Inheritance
docs.text:
@type OrderItem extends BaseItem {
  quantity: number
  price: number
}

docs.title: Field Constraints
docs.text:
@type User {
  email: string, required
  age: number, optional
  role: string, "User role in system"
}

docs.title: Test Blocks
docs.text:
Define test cases with @test:

@test [add] {
  add(1, 2) == 3
  add(0, 0) == 0
  add(-5, 5) == 0
}

@test [divide] {
  divide(10, 2) == 5.0
  divide(9, 3) == 3.0
}

Test blocks generate executable pytest code.

docs.title: Literal Blocks
docs.text:
Escape hatch for exact code when needed:

[slugify]
PURPOSE: Convert text to URL-friendly slug format
INPUTS:
  - text: string

@literal python {
import re

def slugify(text: str) -> str:
    """Convert text to URL-friendly slug format."""
    text = text.lower().strip()
    text = re.sub(r'\s+', '-', text)
    text = re.sub(r'[^a-z0-9-]', '', text)
    return text.strip('-')
}

Literal blocks bypass the compiler and emit code exactly as written.

docs.title: Comments
docs.text:
Lines starting with # are comments:

# Math Module
# This provides basic arithmetic operations

@module math
@target python

# Addition function
[add]
PURPOSE: Add two numbers
...

docs.title: Formatting Notes
docs.text:
1. Bullets are flexible: •, -, or *
  2. Arrows are flexible: → (Unicode) or -> (ASCII)
  3. Section headers are case-insensitive
  4. Indentation uses spaces for visual structure
  5. Unicode is supported in text content

docs.text: For the complete formal grammar, see nl-grammar.ebnf.
